title: Momentum - change in momentum during collision

content.description: A small block of mass <math alttext="lowercase m" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> is moving to the right with a constant speed <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> across a horizontal table. A large block of mass <math alttext="uppercase M" overflow="scroll"> <mi>M</mi> </math> is at rest on the table. The small block collides with and sticks to the larger block, as shown. Frictional forces between both blocks and the table are negligible.
content.question: Which of the following provides a correct prediction about the change in the momentum of the two-block system with correct justification?

choices.label: The change in momentum of the system is negative because kinetic energy is lost in the collision.
The change in momentum of the system is negative because the blocks have a speed less than <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> after the collision.
The change in momentum of the system is zero because there is no net external force exerted on the system.
The change in momentum of the system is zero because the kinetic energy of the system is constant during the collision.

content.answer: The change in momentum of the system is zero because there is no net external force exerted on the system.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
